channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - HP Hero
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2021 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Health officials worry that Covid-19 may end up being like the flu, which requires a new vaccine every year
item.description: Ian Haydon helped test Moderna's coronavirus vaccine last year. Now, he's helping test the tweaked version of that vaccine designed to fight a new, more contagious variant.

item.title: Michigan adds more than 8,400 new Covid-19 cases in one day, the most since December
item.description: Michigan reported 8,413 new Covid-19 cases on Saturday, bringing the state's total pandemic case count to 692,206, according to the state's health department.

item.title: 'That's a confession': Tapper on Trump's statement on his handling of pandemic
item.description: CNN's Jake Tapper shares his experience receiving the Covid-19 vaccine and looks back at how former President Donald Trump's actions affected the nation's pandemic response.

item.title: Mississippi GOP governor pushes back on vaccine passports
item.description: Mississippi's Republican governor said Sunday that he doesn't support the potential use of so-called Covid-19 vaccine passports in his state, calling the credentials that could be key to a return to normalcy by the end of the year unnecessary.

item.title: Florida governor bans Covid-19 'vaccine passports'
item.description: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis signed an executive order Friday banning the use of Covid-19 passports in the state.

item.title: How long Pfizer says its vaccine protection could last
item.description: Pfizer said its vaccine can protect against Covid-19 for at least six months, but experts say that protection will likely last longer.

item.title: ACLU warns 'a lot can go wrong' with digital vaccine passports
item.description: The American Civil Liberties Union says plans to roll out a standardized vaccine passport must account for social inequalities and privacy rights. Anything short is a "nonstarter."

item.title: Think twice before laminating your new vaccine card
item.description: • Live updates: 'We're just at the beginning of this surge' in the US, disease expert says • Analysis: Some are acting like the pandemic is over. It's not • Fauci says this might curb another surge • Dr. Fauci: This is not going to last forever

item.title: Why Republicans can claim to be the party of the White working class
item.description: • Opinion: How much further will fame, spectacle and controversy get Donald Trump?

item.title: Analysis: The Georgia GOP is betting companies criticizing voting law will blink first
item.description: • Omar: Boycotts have 'allowed for justice' from civil rights to ending apartheid • Fact-check: Biden slams Georgia voting bill

item.title: Cyber experts: Half a billion Facebook users' information posted on hacking website
item.description: The personal information of about half a billion Facebook users, including their phone numbers, have been posted to a website used by hackers, cybersecurity experts say.

item.title: Why Rep. Omar disagrees with Abrams about MLB decision
item.description: Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN) speaks to CNN's Jake Tapper about Georgia's new voting law that critics deem restrictive, and Major League Baseball's decision to move its All-Star game out of Atlanta in response to the law.

item.title: The Great Depression led to many of the hobbies we enjoy now. The pandemic created a whole host of new ones
item.description: In the 1930s, it was the game of Bridge that kept people busy during the Great Depression.

item.title: An Asian woman was fatally stabbed while walking her dogs in California, but police say they don't suspect a hate crime
item.description: An elderly Asian woman was stabbed to death while walking her dogs Saturday morning in Riverside, California, police said. But investigators say they don't think it's a hate crime.

item.title: He was put in solitary confinement at age 15 and left there for 18 years
item.description: When Ian Manuel was 13, he shot a woman during a robbery. Although she survived, he was sentenced to life imprisonment without parole, and served 18 years in solitary. CNN's Michael Smerconish talks to Manuel about how he survived and was granted his release.

item.title: Jordan's former crown prince says he has been placed in isolation
item.description: Jordanian royal family member Hassan bin Zaid and former head of the royal court Basem Awadallah were arrested on Saturday due to "security reasons," according to state media Petra.

item.title: The Bidens encourage Americans to get vaccinated in Easter message
item.description: • Biden's wave of pandemic optimism shifts • Analysis: Democrats have a chance to invest in economic growth

item.title: Fareed: Can Biden make the US government great again?
item.description: Fareed Zakaria gives his take on how President Biden's infrastructure plan could restore America's faith in the effectiveness of government.

item.title: Hunter Biden says he's 'absolutely certain' he'll be cleared of wrongdoing in DOJ probe into business dealings
item.description: Hunter Biden says he is fully cooperating with the Justice Department's investigation into his business dealings in China and predicted that he will be cleared of any wrong doing in the probe.

item.title: A week of compelling and potentially devastating testimony at Derek Chauvin's murder trial
item.description: Pain, trauma and regret spilled out from a Minneapolis courtroom during a first week of critical testimony in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who knelt on the neck of George Floyd.

item.title: Analysis: A small town in Alabama now has Amazon on edge
item.description: For more than two decades, Amazon has bulldozed over bricks-and-mortar businesses, hired and churned through vast numbers of workers and even pitted cities against each other to bid for its second headquarters, all in service to its seemingly bottomless thirst for growth and satisfying customers. Its dominance was only further cemented in the last year by the pandemic, as households across the country leaned on the company for deliveries.

item.title: DMX suffered a heart attack and is on life support, lawyer says
item.description: Rapper DMX is hospitalized and on life support at a hospital in White Plains, New York, his longtime attorney Murray Richman confirmed to CNN.

item.title: 'SNL's' Colin Jost takes aim at QAnon following Matt Gaetz controversy
item.description: "Saturday Night Live" host Daniel Kaluuya compares American and British racism, poked fun at people not getting vaccinated and Rep. Matt Gaetz.

item.title: Floods, landslides, kill dozens in Indonesia and East Timor
item.description: Flash floods unleashed by torrential rains killed 41 people on the Indonesian island of Flores on Sunday, the disaster management agency BNPB said, and at least three more were reported killed in neighbouring East Timor.

item.title: Opinion: Trial over George Floyd's killing breaks hearts
item.description: The word "trauma" made its way into the English language from the ancient Greek verb that means to "penetrate." The first known use of it came in 1693 when it was described as "a wound from an external cause." But today our notion of trauma goes beyond the physical to include the extreme mental anguish that can penetrate lives.

item.title: Boy makes 68 million-year-old discovery on hike
item.description: An eighth grader in Colorado found a Tyrannosaurus rex tooth while out on a hike and turned the tooth over to the Denver Museum of Nature and Science.

item.title: A man won $100,000 in the lottery two weeks after winning $5,000
item.description: A North Carolina man who won $5,000 with a scratch-off lottery ticket said he was "extremely happy and surprised" to learn he'd won another $100,000 just two weeks later.

item.title: Opinion: What will it take for the GOP to dump Gaetz?
item.description: Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz, to borrow a phrase from the late singer Tom Petty, is free fallin'.

item.title: 'Space Jam' trailer sees LeBron James dunking with Bugs Bunny
item.description: The "Space Jam: A New Legacy" trailer stars LeBron James as the franchise's new basketball hero, with plenty of nods to the 1996 Michael Jordan classic.

item.title: A loose cow trotting along an Atlanta-area interstate ties up traffic for an hour
item.description: Atlanta-area drivers are used to sitting in traffic, but for those on Interstate 285 this weekend, the cause for their delay was unusual: a loose cow on the highway.

item.title: Tennis stars announce engagement
item.description: It's official! Elina Svitolina and Gael Monfils are engaged after the tennis power couple announced the news on social media.

item.title: SNL calls out Georgia for its new voting law in cold open
item.description: • Analysis: The Georgia GOP is betting companies criticizing voting law will blink first

item.title: How to watch the 27th Annual SAG Awards tonight at 9 p.m. ET
item.description: The 27th Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards, which honor achievement in film and television performances for 2020, will take place this weekend after multiple delays due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Gonzaga defeats UCLA with buzzer beater and will face Baylor in NCAA men's basketball title game
item.description: Baylor University will play for the NCAA men's basketball title after it beat the University of Houston on Saturday 78-59.

item.title: Suspect arrested in the death of a teenage girl who disappeared 45 years ago
item.description: Evelyn Colon was one of five siblings in Jersey City, New Jersey, when she got pregnant in 1976 at age 15 by her 19-year-old boyfriend, Luis Sierra.

item.title: Virginia Beach police ask for the public's help after a triple shooting
item.description: A triple shooting in Virginia Beach, Virginia, left one person dead and two others injured Saturday night, police said.

item.title: The US saw significant crime rise across major cities in 2020. And it's not letting up
item.description: Major American cities saw a 33% increase in homicides last year as a pandemic swept across the country, millions of people joined protests against racial injustice and police brutality, and the economy collapsed under the weight of the pandemic — a crime surge that has continued into the first quarter of this year.

item.title: The Americans who bought a house in Italy over the internet
item.description: How many of us have been sitting at home, seen a dreamy picture of a foreign country, and started planning our life there?

item.title: Find out which countries are welcoming US tourists back
item.description: Once one of the world's most powerful travel documents, the might of the United States passport has been diminished during the pandemic. With US Covid-19 cases past the 30.6 million mark, some nations continue to view vacationers warily.

item.title: In San Francisco, a new kind of team is replacing police for some 911 calls
item.description: Amid protests calling for alternative services to police responders, cities have started implementing crisis response teams to replace police officers for certain 911 calls. In San Francisco, a new street crisis response team is comprised of behavioral and mental health experts who respond to non-violent incidents. We follow along as the unit patrols the streets and helps out individuals experiencing mental health crises, and speak to Addie Kitchen, who says a team like this could have saved her grandson's life. CNN's Chris James reports.

item.title: Rare video game sells for a record $660,000
item.description: After being forgotten in a desk drawer for almost 35 years, a sealed copy of the Nintendo video game Super Mario Bros. sold at auction on Friday for a whopping $660,000.

item.title: Why I had to sell my wedding ring to keep my business alive
item.description: I signed the lease to open my first salon, The Bare Bar on Valentine's Day 2020, less than a month before the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a pandemic. I remember having butterflies in my stomach when I signed my name. I was one big step closer to starting my own business, a dream that I'd been working toward for eight years. I'd recently sold my family's dream home and used that money to start the salon. A year later, I've sold my wedding ring to keep it going and have done everything I can to keep this dream alive -- except take out a Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loan. I'm not eligible for one because The Bare Bar didn't open its doors until after February 15, 2020.

item.title: Billionaire says he's 'completely disenchanted' with America after attacks on Asian Americans
item.description: Patrick Soon-Shiong, the billionaire owner of the Los Angeles Times, is urging America to admit it has a racism problem.

item.title: High fees and pricey cowboy boots: Why crypto spending isn't about to go mainstream
item.description: Last month, I set out to buy my father, an avid Before the Bell reader, a non-fungible token, or NFT.

Boehner is right about GOP before Trump
item.description: During Donald Trump's presidency, many of his critics argued that he was the cause of so many problems plaguing the country and the Republican Party. While Trump was far from innocent, as a former member of Congress and lifelong Republican, I have never bought the simplicity of that argument.

item.title: Jill Biden is a long way from cookie bake-offs
item.description: Dr. Jill Biden is back in the classroom this month, carrying a course load of three classes as she returns to her full-time teaching job at Northern Virginia Community College. Her work looks a bit different after a year off on the campaign trail. Two of the classes are hybrid, featuring live-streamed instruction as part of the Covid protocols not yet necessary when she took a leave of absence last January. She also returns with a new title: First lady of the United States.

item.title: Gaetz's diversionary tactics aren't working
item.description: It is now public knowledge that Rep. Matt Gaetz is under investigation by the Justice Department, which is reportedly looking into whether he paid for the travel expenses of a 17-year-old girl across state lines to entice her into sexual activity. And Gaetz did not take the breaking of the news quietly.

item.title: How America's all-volunteer force reshaped military
item.description: Over the last year, the pandemic -- with all its human tragedies and socioeconomic consequences, as well as the November election and its contested and violent aftermath -- has dominated the nation's attention.

item.title: Why I can't watch the Chauvin trial
item.description: Confession.

item.title: Problem with Biden isn't his trips, note cards or dogs
item.description: Last week, many conservative pundits spent time focused on two incidents that they argue exposed President Joe Biden's shortcomings. The first was his tripping and falling while on the stairs leading up to Air Force One and the second was his use of extensive notes (which some analysts referred to as a script) during the first press conference of his presidency.
